item.title: The Second Bakery Attack
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: I'm still not sure I made the right choice when I told my wife about the bakery attack.

item.title: A Long Way From Stuffed Cabbage
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: Sometimes I meet a person who says I've had so many interesting experiences that I can write lots of books about them.

item.title: Princeton
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: It was in the summer of 1984 that I visited Princeton, New Jersey for the first time.

item.title: On seeing the 100% perfect girl one beautiful April morning
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: One beautiful April morning, on a narrow side street in Tokyo's fashionable Harujuku neighborhood, I walked past the 100% perfect girl.

item.title: Honey Pie
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: "So Masakichi got his paws full of honey—way more honey than he could eat by himself—and he put it in a pail...

item.title: Landscape with Flatiron
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: Junko was watching television when the phone rang a few minutes before midnight.

item.title: Kino
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: The man always sat in the same seat, the stool farthest down the counter.

item.title: Samsa in Love
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: He woke to discover that he had undergone a metamorphosis and become Gregor Samsa.

item.title: Yesterday
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: As far as I know, the only person ever to put Japanese lyrics to the Beatles song “Yesterday”.

item.title: Town of Cats
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: At Koenji Station, Tengo boarded the Chuo Line inbound rapid-service train. The car was empty.

item.title: UFO in Kushiro
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: Short story about a Japanese man who attempts to piece together his reaction to his divorce by taking a trip north to bleak Hokkaido.

item.title: A Walk to Kobe
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: In May of 1997, two years after the massive earthquake in Kobe, I hit upon the idea of taking a leisurely, solitary walk from Nishinomiya to Sannomiya in downtown Kobe.

item.title: The Kidney-Shaped Stone That Moves Every Day
item.dc:creator: Haruki Murakami
item.description: Junpei was sixteen years old when his father made a surprising pronouncement.
